rename.from: now removing files Encrypted Amazon Cloud Drive
rename.to: not removing files Encrypted Amazon Cloud Drive

rename.from: not removing files Encrypted Amazon Cloud Drive

body:
I noticed the same behavior and believe it is intentional but undocumented that a move that doesn't actually involve a copy isn't destructive.

http://rclone.org/commands/rclone_move/

Notes that

> If possible a server side move will be used, otherwise it will copy it (server side if possible) into dest:path then delete the original (if no errors on copy) in source:path.

I believe this should be

> If possible a server side move will be used, otherwise it will copy it (server side if possible) into dest:path then delete the original (if the file was moved) in source:path.

To cover the case where you skip copying of the local copy because it matches the already uploaded file.

It seems like odd behavior because it's a 'move'. If it encounters the same file on the destination(size, etc match), then the intent of the 'move' should remove that file from the source.  I don't want to have to use the -I all of the time to get the behavior I need because it's forcing the re-transferring of data that is already good. It's wasting resources. Maybe we need another option that is destructive if this was done intentionally.

I don't actually see the -l argument documented either. What is the command supposed to do?

I think the closest analog is rsync with "--remove-source-files" which does function as would be expected - if the source files already exist at the destination they are removed, even if they were not copied.

I found it in the rclone --help.

-I, --ignore-times                    Don't skip files that match size and time - transfer all files

so its transferring  the files again. This isnt a big deal on small jpegs but it is a big deal on Multi-GB files. This will transfer the file again and clean it up on the source.

I know the intended behavior is to leave directories behind so I clean those up with this after the move. 
find /path/to/source -empty -type d -delete

I noticed it wasnt cleaning up the directories and thats when I saw that there were files left behind.

issue.title: Minor Documentation Fixes

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body: Fix to clarify behavior for issue #751. Fix to recommended max file size argument for Amazon Cloud Drive.

body: #754 updates the documentation to reflect this behavior.

I think this is a bug - `move` should move the files and if an identical file exists in the destination then the source file should be deleted.  This is what would happen if it was copied

Here is a demo of the problem.

```
$ mkdir /tmp/a /tmp/b
$ echo hellp >/tmp/a/test.txt
$ rclone -q copy /tmp/a /tmp/b
$ rclone move -v /tmp/a /tmp/b
2016/10/01 17:08:33 rclone: Version "v1.33-DEV" starting with parameters ["rclone" "move" "-v" "/tmp/a" "/tmp/b"]
2016/10/01 17:08:33 Local file system at /tmp/b: Modify window is 1ns
2016/10/01 17:08:33 Local file system at /tmp/b: Using server side directory move
2016/10/01 17:08:33 Local file system at /tmp/b: Server side directory move failed - fallback to file moves: can't copy directory - destination already exists
2016/10/01 17:08:33 Local file system at /tmp/b: Waiting for checks to finish
2016/10/01 17:08:33 test.txt: Size and modification time the same (differ by 0s, within tolerance 1ns)
2016/10/01 17:08:33 test.txt: Unchanged skipping
2016/10/01 17:08:33 Local file system at /tmp/b: Waiting for transfers to finish
2016/10/01 17:08:33 
Transferred:      0 Bytes (0 Bytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 1
Transferred:            0
Elapsed time:          0s
2016/10/01 17:08:33 Go routines at exit 3
$ rclone -q ls /tmp/a
        6 test.txt
```

rename.to: move not remove files from the source that already exist in the destination

body:
I think the behavior should be changed as well.

At a minimum, if it is not changed, the documentation needs to be updated.
On Sat, Oct 1, 2016 at 9:10 AM Nick Craig-Wood notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I think this is a bug - move should move the files and if an identical
> file exists in the destination then the source file should be deleted. This
> is what would happen if it was copied

If you find any problems then please re-open the ticket!
